entries.meaning: Evil, especially considered as an active force for destruction or death.

description: From Middle English bale (‚Äúpyre, funeral pyre‚Äù), from Old English b«£l (‚Äúpyre, funeral pyre‚Äù), from Proto-Germanic *bƒìlƒÖ (‚Äúpyre‚Äù), from Proto-Indo-European *b ∞el- (‚Äúto shine; gleam; sparkle‚Äù). entries.meaning: (obsolete) A large fire, a conflagration or bonfire.

description: From Middle English bale (‚Äúbale‚Äù), from Old French bale and Medieval Latin bala, of Germanic origin. Doublet of ball.

entries.meaning: A rounded bundle or package of goods in a cloth cover, and corded for storage or transportation.
examples: So having made up my mind, I packed up in bales a quantity of precious stuffs suited for sea-trade and repaired with them from Baghdad-city to Bassorah-town, where I found ship ready for sea, and in her a company of considerable merchants.

entries.meaning: A bundle of compressed wool or hay, compacted for shipping and handling.
A measurement of hay equal to 10 flakes. Approximately 70-90 lbs (32-41 kg).
A measurement of paper equal to 10 reams.

verbs.description: bale (third-person singular simple present bales, present participle baling, simple past and past participle baled)
bale (third-person singular simple present bales, present participle baling, simple past and past participle baled)

entries.meaning: (Britain, nautical) To remove water from a boat with buckets etc.
